name: 1598_D. Training Session
description:
Monocarp is the coach of the Berland State University programming teams. He decided to compose a problemset for a training session for his teams.

Monocarp has n problems that none of his students have seen yet. The i-th problem has a topic a_i (an integer from 1 to n) and a difficulty b_i (an integer from 1 to n). All problems are different, that is, there are no two tasks that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

Monocarp decided to select exactly 3 problems from n problems for the problemset. The problems should satisfy at least one of two conditions (possibly, both):

  * the topics of all three selected problems are different; 
  * the difficulties of all three selected problems are different. 



Your task is to determine the number of ways to select three problems for the problemset.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.
repair_prompt:
Monocarp wants to ensure the selected problems provide a good balance of challenge and opportunity for the students to learn.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Note

  * problems 1, 2, 4;

Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp strives to create a selection of problems that offer students both a challenging experience and an opportunity to learn and grow from their efforts. The aim is to strike a perfect balance between challenge and learning potential in the chosen problems.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp wants to ensure the selected problems provide a good balance of challenge and opportunity for the students to learn.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

completions:
from itertools import combinations

t = int(input())

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = []
    for _ in range(n):
        a, b = map(int, input().split())
        problems.append((a, b))

    all_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))

    valid_combinations = []
    for comb in all_combinations:
        topics = set()
        difficulties = set()
        for prob in comb:
            topics.add(prob[0])
            difficulties.add(prob[1])
        if len(topics) == 3 or len(difficulties) == 3:
            valid_combinations.append(comb)

    num_valid_combinations = len(valid_combinations)

    print(num_valid_combinations)

main()

def count_ways_to_select_problems():
    t = int(input())  # Number of testcases
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())  # Number of problems
        topics = {}  # Dictionary to store the count of each topic
        difficulties = {}  # Dictionary to store the count of each difficulty
        for _ in range(n):
            a, b = map(int, input().split())
            topics[a] = topics.get(a, 0) + 1
            difficulties[b] = difficulties.get(b, 0) + 1
        
        total_ways = 0
        for topic_count in topics.values():
            # Calculate the number of ways to select three problems with the same topic
            total_ways += topic_count * (topic_count - 1) * (topic_count - 2) // 6
        
        for difficulty_count in difficulties.values():
            # Calculate the number of ways to select three problems with the same difficulty
            total_ways += difficulty_count * (difficulty_count - 1) * (difficulty_count - 2) // 6
        
        # Calculate the number of ways to select three problems with different topics and difficulties
        for topic_count in topics.values():
            for difficulty_count in difficulties.values():
                total_ways += topic_count * (topic_count - 1) * (topic_count - 2) // 6 * difficulty_count * (difficulty_count - 1) * (difficulty_count - 2) // 6
        
        print(total_ways)

count_ways_to_select_problems()

main()

from itertools import combinations

t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = [list(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]

    all_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))

    valid_combinations = [comb for comb in all_combinations if 
                          (comb[0][0] != comb[1][0] and comb[1][0] != comb[2][0] and comb[0][0] != comb[2][0]) or 
                          (comb[0][1] != comb[1][1] and comb[1][1] != comb[2][1] and comb[0][1] != comb[2][1])]

    num_valid_combinations = len(valid_combinations)

    print(num_valid_combinations)

main()

from itertools import combinations

t = int(input())

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = []
    for _ in range(n):
        a, b = map(int, input().split())
        problems.append((a, b))

    all_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))

    valid_combinations = [comb for comb in all_combinations if len(set([topic for topic, _ in comb])) == 3 or len(set([difficulty for _, difficulty in comb])) == 3]

    num_ways = len(valid_combinations)

    print(num_ways)

main()

t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = [list(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]

Round_0.code:
from itertools import combinations

# Parse the input to extract the number of testcases and the details of each testcase
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = []
    for _ in range(n):
        a, b = map(int, input().split())
        problems.append((a, b))

    # For each testcase, create a list of all possible combinations of 3 problems
    all_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))

    # Filter the combinations to only include those that meet the requirements (topic and difficulty)
    valid_combinations = [comb for comb in all_combinations if len(set([topic for topic, _ in comb])) == 3 or len(set([difficulty for _, difficulty in comb])) == 3]

    # Count the number of valid combinations
    num_ways = len(valid_combinations)

    # Output the result for each testcase
    print(num_ways)

from itertools import combinations

t = int(input())

for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    problems = []
    for _ in range(n):
        a, b = map(int, input().split())
        problems.append((a, b))

    all_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))

    valid_combinations = [comb for comb in all_combinations if len(set([topic for topic, _ in comb])) == 3 or len(set([difficulty for _, difficulty in comb])) == 3]

    num_ways = len(valid_combinations)

    print(num_ways)

prompt:
Monocarp wants to ensure the selected problems provide a good balance of challenge and opportunity for the students to learn.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.
